docs.lead_paragraph: Adults and children from the Americas to Western Europe and the Middle East must roughly halve the amount of sugar they consume to lower risk of obesity and tooth decay, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Slash Sugar Intake to Fight Obesity, Tooth Decay: WHO
headline.print_headline: Slash Sugar Intake to Fight Obesity, Tooth Decay: WHO

docs.snippet: Adults and children from the Americas to Western Europe and the Middle East must roughly halve the amount of sugar they consume to lower risk of obesity and tooth decay, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health officials say people should eat less sugar. But that's easier said than done.

headline.main: How Much Sugar Is in That? 7 Foods With Added Sugar
headline.print_headline: How Much Sugar Is in That? 7 Foods With Added Sugar

docs.snippet: Health officials say people should eat less sugar. But that's easier said than done.

docs.lead_paragraph: New guidelines from the World Health Organization are enough to kill anyone's sugar high. The U.N. health agency says the world is eating too much sugar and people should slash their intake to just six to 12 teaspoons per day — an amount that could be exceeded with a single can of soda.

headline.main: UN: World Eating Too Much Sugar; Cut to 5-10 Percent of Diet

docs.lead_paragraph: The money, for pilot programs, is part of a broader push to address persistent poverty and childhood hunger in rural areas.

headline.main: Three States and Two Tribes to Get $27 Million to Fight Childhood Hunger
headline.print_headline: Three States and Two Tribes to Get $27 Million to Fight Childhood Hunger

docs.abstract: Obama administration says it will commit $27 million to fund demonstration projects providing food to children and families in rural areas as part of effort to address poverty and childhood hunger there; rural areas of United States have lagged behind economic progress seen elsewhere.
docs.snippet: The money, for pilot programs, is part of a broader push to address persistent poverty and childhood hunger in rural areas.

docs.abstract: We are very fond of the word “swath,” using it well over 200 times a year in recent years. Unfortunately, many of those uses are at best distantly related to the word’s precise meaning.
docs.snippet: We are very fond of the word “swath,” using it well over 200 times a year in recent years. Unfortunately, many of those uses are at best distantly related to the word’s precise meaning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charlotte Glauser, a reader, writes that the advice must “take into account what is and is not demonstrable.”
docs.snippet: Charlotte Glauser, a reader, writes that the advice must “take into account what is and is not demonstrable.”

docs.lead_paragraph: In one of the world’s most perplexing public health issues, Indian mothers tend to be less healthy than their counterparts in poorer countries.

headline.main: Study Says Pregnant Women in India Are Gravely Underweight
headline.print_headline: While India Is Booming, Mothers Go Hungry

docs.abstract: Study published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences finds that India's high infant mortality rate can be blamed on relatively poor health of mothers; many young women are severely anemic due to poor sanitation and cultural bias that allows them less food than other family members.
docs.snippet: In one of the world’s most perplexing public health issues, Indian mothers tend to be less healthy than their counterparts in poorer countries.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: How supplements became ubiquitous in our food and in our stores, even though evidence they work is scant.
docs.abstract: Christie Aschwanden reviews book Vitamania: Our Obsessive Quest for Nutritional Perfection by Catherine Price.

headline.main: Should Pregnant Women Eat More Tuna?

docs.abstract: For years pregnant women have been warned about eating tuna because of worries about mercury exposure. But now a federal panel has reignited the debate about the benefits and risks.
docs.snippet: For years pregnant women have been warned about eating tuna because of worries about mercury exposure. But now a federal panel has reignited the debate about the benefits and risks.
